Description: East Greek terracotta mould-made figure. Head of Herakles in the form of a vase, with the mouth missing. Beardless, with lion's head worn as a hat, lion's upper jaw resting on Herakles forehead, lower jaw resting on his cheeks. Traces of red paint or slip remain on Herakles' skin and the lion's ears. Traces of black paint around Herakles and the lions eyes and pupil also remain. Hollow from a two piece mould. Buff to pale pink fabric with frequent fine silver mica, angular quartz, limestone and black (igneous?) inclusions.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Walters identifies a close Late Archaic parallel from Cameiros, Rhodes (1903, 120, no. B286, BM Terracotta), though Higgins suggests it is earlier than this example (1954, 46, no. 50, BM Terracotta I) providing a 6th century BC date. Though found in Rhodes, a South Ionian origin is most likely.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (50)
Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (p. 41, pl. XV, no.7)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.030) (Phase 1)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2016, 19 May-27 Nov, BM exhibition Sunken Treasures
